title: Can atheists debunk the claims about science in the Quran? - Quora

response.answer_text: Atheists can not debunk what they know nothing about. The Quran is much above their knowledge and ability to understand. Not only atheists, even muslims they dont get it well. It is not a book of science, and has nothing to do with science theories and manners to find facts about this universe. It is a timeline of creation from the very beginning to the very end, sequenced creations and end step by step in sequence. Atheists say this is impossible, and it doesnt work to have a timeline. Well, this is the best they can do ….. disagree on what they know nothing about. I read an example given to show how no science in the Quran “So verily I swear by the stars that run and hide ... and say it predicts black holes. It does not. First, of course, black holes do not run and hide. Second, this verse describes none of the key facts about black holes — that they are very massive and very dense, that light can’t escape, that they have a radius inside of which nothing can escape and so on. Or they take "[I swear by] the Moon in her fullness; that ye shall journey on from stage to stage" He means the Ayah “ i dont swear in the dim ones” , “ that are flowing residing in homes” The Ayah is not exactly as the writer translated it, and is not related to the black holes in any way. The negative swear in the Ayat is to define that the subject of the Ayah is not stable. It is describing the condition of the universe when it is close to its end. It is describing the skies of the galaxies after all matter goes out of them, the energy forming them which is the fifth energy weakens dim unobservable and that fifth energy flows back to the homes they spread from when inflation of the big bang ended. Following it there are two Ayat “ and if the night loses its transparency” “ and if the morning breathes” These two Ayat describes that when the skies of the galaxies reside at their homes, the space time sky starts to lose its transparency moving back to its morning stage when it was foggy. A stage when the electro magnetic waves will be in its earliest and longest wave. The second Ayah he mentioned not found in the Quran, he translated it the way he understood it. There is Ayah “ Never. WA , the moon” “ and the night if showed its back” “ and the morning showed up” … These Ayat are not describing the moon journey. What journey? These Ayat are part of the end of the universe events a stage following the events mentioned in the Ayat i described above. They are telling that after the night of the space time sky about to have its transparency ends and the morning of that skies about to become complete. Again, the morning of that sky is the stage when it becomes foggy and the electromagnetic waves are at their longest. In a following Ayah tells that these events are part of the biggest happenings in the life of this universe. The claimed journey of the moon is not one of the biggest happenings in this universe life. Mentioning the moon is a code that leads to another group of Ayat in a different Surah describes what happens to earth by giving the moon as part of the description. This is why i said no one can debunk something that he has no idea of whether atheists or any other human. This is part of timeline, conclusions sequences the happenings of this universe. Myself, a believer in every word in this creation timeline of the Quran, dont have the interest to debunk atheists theories though i know where many of their theories fail and why, and where they are progressing. On the contrary, i ask them to work harder and reach to what they want to know.

Hello, Tajrian Hossain, and welcome to Quora! Q: Can atheists debunk the claims about science in the Quran? Sure! In fact, there are entire websites devoted to debunking various claims made by Muslims about “impossibly accurate scientific statements” supposedly found in the Qur’an. For example: Islamic Science: Does Islamic literature contain scientific miracles? Science in the Qur’an? Surely you’re joking, Mr. Muslim! Scientific Miracles in the Quran But, if you’re not interested in actually reading any of that information (perhaps out of fear of actually learning something and having your faith shaken as a result), let me just make two simple observations: Many different religions have an ancient holy book that some believers are convinced contains “impossibly accurate scientific statements” that prove the book is of divine origin. Not just Islam and its Qur’an, but also Christianity and its Bible, Hinduism and its Vedas and even Zorastrianism and its Avesta. So if you accept Islam’s claims as proof that the Qur’an is divinely inspired, you must also accept these other claims as well.Not surprisingly, these supposedly “accurate scientific statements” that appear in all these different texts only ever manage to be interpreted in the “right” way after science has made a discovery and somebody goes looking for any passages that could vaguely be interpreted to match. Not once has anybody ever interpreted the passages correctly up front. [More Maude & Eugene cartoons can be found at The Ongoing Adventures of “Maude and Eugene”.]  Note: My former Quora blog "Common Sense Atheism" has now been converted into a "Space" at Common Sense Atheism. If you like what I write, please consider following my Space so you can be notified when I add new content.

According to the Qur’an, one of the excuses that Muhammad’s contemporaries gave for rejecting his mission was that they wanted to see a supernatural event, a miracle, confirming his sincerity: They say: “We will not believe for you [Muhammad] until you make a spring gush out of the ground for us; or until you have a garden of date palms and vines, and make rivers pour through them; or make the sky fall on us in pieces, as you claimed will happen; or bring God and the angels before us face to face; or have a house made of gold, or ascend into the sky—even then, we will not believe in your ascension until you send a real book down for us to read.” (17:90–93, also see 6:8–10, 52:44–45, 6:33–35, etc.) The Qur’anic response to such a demand is very interesting and instructive. First, it highlights the real task of the prophet. He is not meant to be a wonderworker; rather, he is merely a human being whose duty is to convey a message revealed to him, inviting people to recognize their one God: “Say, ‘Glory to my Lord! Am I anything but a mortal, a messenger?’ ” (Q. 17:93); “Say, ‘I am only a human being, like you, to whom it has been revealed that your God is One’ ” (Q. 18:110). The message that the messenger brings is a sufficient sign in itself, validating the truthfulness of the messenger who proclaims it. In fact, the Qur’an describes itself—the very revelation of this enlightening message to an “unlettered” man—as a sign that points to God (Q. 2:23, 17:88, etc.). The Qur’an repeatedly challenges it's audience to produce such a discourse on their own: “If you have doubts about the revelation We have sent down to Our servant, then produce a single sura like it—enlist whatever supporters you have other than God—if you truly [think you can]” (Q. 2:23). And in a provocative way it reframes the challenge: “Say [Muhammad], ‘Even if all mankind and jinn came together to produce something like this Qur’an, they could not produce anything like it, however much they helped each other’ ” (17:88; see also 10:38, 11:13, 52:33–34). At other times, the Qur’an responds to the demands for a supernatural event by noting that previous people often did not believe even when they saw miracles (Q. 5:110, 10:75–77, 17:59, 27:10–13, etc.). As , it seems that the Qur’an deems miracles as almost “out of date.”4 The disbelievers will still not believe even if they see the miracles they demand: “Even if We had sent down to you [Prophet] a book inscribed on parchment, and they had touched it with their own hands, the disbelievers would still say, ‘This is clearly sorcery’ ” (Q. 6:7). Similarly, “even if they saw a piece of heaven falling down on them, they would say, ‘Just a heap of clouds’ ” (Q. 52:44). Finally, the Qur’an responds to the demands for miracles from Muhammad by citing natural phenomena. The idea is that nature contains sufficient evidence for the central claims of the Qur’an, namely the reality of God and life after death. Indeed, the term the Qur’an uses for miracles, āya, is the same term used for natural phenomena (e.g., Q. 2:264, 7:107–8, 13:3, 16:65–72, 29:42, 30:20–27, etc.). The Qur’an repeatedly talks about natural processes—such as the rain, wind, stars, sun, moon, grains, fruits, growth of an embryo, production of milk and honey, sailing of ships on water, variety of human races, and so on—as signs, āyāt, that disclose a transcendental source of mercy, power, and wisdom. For instance, “In the creation of the heavens and earth; in the alteration of night and day; in the ships that sail the seas with goods for people; in the water which God sends down from the sky to give life to the earth when it has been barren, scattering all kinds of creatures over it; in the changing of the winds and clouds that run their appointed courses between the sky and earth: there are signs [āyāt] in all these for those who use their minds” (Q. 2:164, ) The presentation of natural phenomena as signs of God is actually a major theme in the Qur’an; nature is “the prime miracle of God, cited untiringly.”5 The Qur’an claims that these “natural signs” are visible and clear, and yet one still needs to be trained in order to recognize them. Just as an illiterate person can see a piece of writing clearly but will not be able to read it until he is taught how to read, the signs of God in the world become intelligible only through the teaching of the prophets. Indeed, according to the Qur’an, deciphering the signs of God in nature is the very function of the revelation. Hence, the Qur’an employs the same word, āya, not only for natural events and miracles but also for the message proclaimed by messengers of God. The “signs” or “verses” of the revelation recited by the prophets disclose the “signs” in the universe.6 To be sure, the Qur’an is explicit about the relational aspect of signs of God. Despite the clarity of the signs of scripture and signs in nature, these will be signs only in relation to someone who is open to considering them as such. If one refuses to consider them, the signs cannot force themselves on that person: “However eagerly you may want them to, most men will not believe [in this message]. You ask no reward from them for this: it is a reminder for all people and there are many signs [āyāt] in the heavens and the earth that they pass by and give no heed to” (Q. 12:103–5, miracles,

Yes, I’ve done it before: Habib Fanny's answer to Does the Holy Quran contain scientific facts that were discovered by scientists centuries later? If so, what were they? But I’ve found it to be a useless endeavor. Very few people come from a science background, look at the Quran, then decide that the science contained therein can only be of divine origin. The only people who believe that the Quran is scientific are committed Muslims. You can’t refute it because for them, it’s a matter of faith, not of logic. Everyone else who reads these so-called scientific passages sees in them nothing more than the general understanding of things in Arabia 14 centuries ago. And since they don’t see anything divine in them, there is no point refuting them. That would be like spending time and energy to try to convince people today that Osiris isn’t real.

If this is about the passages regarding foetal development? That knowledge was discovered centuries earlier than it appeared in the Quran by a Greek Physician Galen during the third century. Indeed it appears that’s where the authors of The Quran obtained the account. It isn’t very accurate of course. For example describing an embryo as a blood clot!The description is the sort of thing people who don’t have microscopes might describe through dissection of (we assume animal) specimens. We should recognise it as science in the Quran. It’s not very advanced science and entirely within the reach of the technology of the period or almost any period in human history. Can we debunk the science? Yes, easily. It’s very crude and outright wrong by our modern understanding. But that doesn’t mean it was bad science in its time. Can we debunk the idea that the knowledge is somehow of supernatural origin? Yes. It was previously known and easily obtained with the technology of the period.

There are no claims about science in the Quran. There are vague, almost meaningless verses that people have wildly interpreted as if they were predictions of things. For example, they take the verse So verily I swear by the stars that run and hide ... and say it predicts black holes. It does not. First, of course, black holes do not run and hide. Second, this verse describes none of the key facts about black holes — that they are very massive and very dense, that light can’t escape, that they have a radius inside of which nothing can escape and so on. Or they take "[I swear by] the Moon in her fullness; that ye shall journey on from stage to stage" and imagine that this means humans will go to outer space. And so on. Note that all these “predictions” were only discovered backwards. That is, no one was looking at these verses in 1900 and saying “I bet there are supermassive bodies in space that are so dense that nothing can escape”.

Can atheists debunk the claims about science in the Quran? Scientifically accurate claims make predictions you can falsify by experiment. Where are those claims in the Quran? Where are the experiments that falsify them? I can tell you. The Quran contains no such claims. It contains vague descriptions of things having to do with nature which can be interpreted to match scientific discoveries but only after those discoveries have been made by scientists. That is not the same. It’s like Nostradamus’ prophecies or horoscopes. It only works on people who want it to be true because those are the only people who interpret them that way.

There aren’t any scientific claims made in the Quran which are either true or hadn’t been scientifically worked out prior to its being written. Don’t just believe what your religious indoctrinators tell you - go and learn for yourself. Things the Quran gets completely wrong: The Earth is flat! The Earth was created in six days! The Earth was created before stars! The Earth and the heavens were torn apart There are seven Earths The sun and the moon are joined The moon was split in two and then put back together again The moon emits light / is made of light like the sun Meteors are stars The sky is a dome which covers the flat Earth Shadows move towards Allah which explains their changing shape and size Humans didn’t evolve Humans were created by a clot of blood Bones are formed before flesh (and many, many more)

It does not require atheists to dispute that the Quran is filled with scientific facts, when even Muslim scholars say the same thing. Wikipedia says: As of 2008, both (some) Muslims and non-Muslims have disputed whether there actually are scientific miracles in the Quran. According to author Ziauddin Sardar, the movement has created a "global craze in Muslim societies". Critics argue that while it is generally agreed the Quran contains many verses proclaiming the wonders of nature — such as “Travel throughout the earth and see how He brings life into being” (Q.29:20), “Behold in the creation of the heavens and the earth, and the alternation of night and day, there are indeed signs for men of understanding ...” (Q.3:190) — The ijaz movement is questionable because it requires "considerable mental gymnastics and distortions to find scientific facts or theories in these verses" (Ziauddin Sardar);the Quran is the source of guidance in right faith (iman) and righteous action (alladhina amanu wa amilu l-salihat), but the idea that it contained "all knowledge, including scientific" knowledge has not been a mainstream view among Muslim scholarship (Zafar Ishaq Ansari); and"Science is ever-changing", the Copernican revolution overturned Ptolemy's models of the universe, Einstein’s general relativity overshadowed Newtonian mechanics, (Ali Talib).

Q: Can atheists debunk the claims about science in the Quran? Yes, I did it and many other did The science of the Quran is an obvious lie but Islam is built around fear and superstitions and Muslims really want to believe so they reject the truth Whenever a clear proof debunking the science of the Quran is given, some apologist comes with a stupid explanation. Muslims really want to believe so they are willing to accept any lame justification if it means they can keep the faith Anyone who says he is looking for the truth must be willing to question everything When one starts to question religions he soon realizes they cannot be the truth. Having faith is to declare that you stopped looking for the truth since faith is to believe even against the facts

I suspect that the vast majority of atheists have no wish to debunk anything. Speaking only for myself, I have been approached over time by Jehovah’s Witnesses, Mormons, Plymouth Brethren who have actively tried - without success - to “convert” me. I have read and observed the attempts of assorted other religions to achieve the same aim. I have no responsibility or desire to change anyone’s views of religion, ethics or morality to my own. It is believers who crave the satisfaction of “converting” others. Atheists, most generally, hope you will make up your own mind…and then pursue your beliefs without disturbing other people.

I don’t really understand why theists believe that atheists have to debunk everything their holy book of choice says. The burden of proof falls on the people making the claim, not on those who deny it. But, quite simply, no scientific breakthrough ever relied on any passage of the quran, or the bible, or the torah, or the Silmarillion. Theists always attribute the breakthroughs on passages after the fact. That’s not how this works. You are the one who has to provide evidence that there is an actual connection between the two things that you claim are connected. Can you? Original question: Can atheists debunk the claims about science in the Quran?

It is a fact that there is no evidence for the existence of any gods. Atheists simply accept that fact. Debunking specific claims of specific religions is nothing to do with atheism. Many ancient writings correlate reasonably well with some parts of current science, which makes sense, as the writers were a self-selecting group of relatively well educated people. But ancient writings from non-religious texts, not surprisingly, are much “better”, scientifically, than the non-scientific ones.

Do you mean the clear, concise, specific and unequivocal claims regarding science that could not be known the the authors at that time? Speaking for only one atheist, if you can find such claims I’m prepared to make the attempt. But I’m not interested in vague mumbo-jumbo that could only be interpreted as a “scientific” claim by completely avoiding any plain-sense reading of the words or can only be seen as accurate in hindsight. Q: Can atheists debunk the claims about science in the Quran?

Atheism addresses the single claim of god-belief. Nothing more. It is wishful thinking to imagine that any holy writ contains scientific information. You are, perhaps, confusing it with the interpretation of certain passages upon which you apply current scientific understanding and then jump to the conclusion that it is therefore science. Unfortunately, that is not how science works. Scientific findings are subjected to rigorous peer-review before being accepted as our current best understanding of an aspect of the natural world. This is how the desperate decide that chariots of fire equal modern rockets. When you seek questions to the answers you already have, science is irrelevant.

This is how “science in holy books” work. First, scientists find some new fact or elaborate a new theory. Then, someone combs their own holy book for some obscure passage nobody in history had paid attention to, and says “see, here the Messiah says something that looks a bit like what was discovered, if you twist it enough and use modern meanings for ancient words”.

One of the most frequently invoked examples of scientific prescience in the Quran is the description of fertilisation and the development of the embryo. It is almost verbatim a copy of the works of Galen and Hippocrates published something like 1000 years before the quran was written. It even makes the same errors, for example claiming that sperm comes from “between the backbone and the ribs", presumably meaning the kidneys or that the bones form before the flesh.

The claims have been debunked multiple times and in great detail from experts on the Quran here on Quora.. You have the opportunity, when constructing a question on Quora, to see similar past questions and the answers to them. Looking at this resource would save you a lot of time and embarrassment. I urge you to take on board all the evidence that exists here on Quora. It’s rather impressive.

I don’t know all the scientific claims in the Quran, but I do know what “Shooting Stars” are - The Quran calls them Jinns and claims they are a kind of supernatural evil being. They are, in fact, small lumps of rock from a comet or asteroid vaporizing in our atmosphere. Those that survive the journey and land are called meteorites.

If the Quran already had all these scientific discoveries in it, why didn’t Muslim scholars save the world’s scientists a whole bunch of time and effort and write them all up? Why did they wait for other scientists to discover them? Was it a prank?

Atheists most definitely don’t need to. Atheists see no need to prove, or disprove, any statement, belief, or mythdo not care what you believe, if you don’t attempt to coerce them in any wayBut, if you insist on ‘science in the Quran’, some atheists will tell you: Pfft!

Point to a scientific statement in the Quran that was known to interpreters of the Quran, and remarked on, before it was discovered by scientists. All these claims seem to be based on after the fact, twisted interpretation. Ditto the Jewish and Christian Bible.

I see you got Barry to comment. He still likes to use cartoons to make his point. Other than knowing (as family) a few Muslims, I know nothing of the Quran. I thought it was written before “science” was a thing???
Only desperados claim about science in Quran. You do not have to be an atheist to counter that.
Scientists would be the ones to debunk false science.
They always could and you just never ever admitted then handwaving as “Metaphorical Interpretation”
Sure, but who cares. Your not going to convince anyone with 13th century beliefs.
I’m quite sure that they could, if any such “claims” existed. But they don’t.
I don’t know, why don’t you try being more specific about the “claims about science” in the Quran.
